oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Battle of New Orleans" scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving of Major-General Andrew Jackson, sword aloft, standing with troops behind American ramparts at the Battle of New Orleans. Two frontier militiamen and a black man are in forefront. The black man is rummaging through a bag of musket balls. U.S. regulars fire from behind the cotton-bale barricade while British soldiers attack. Scattered on the ground are a broken drum, a musket, and cannonballs. A tattered American flag waves at top center.

Jackson commanded American troops during the Battle of New Orleans, January 8, 1815. Since transatlantic communication was so slow, the combatants had not yet learned that the Treaty of Ghent ended the War of 1812 two weeks earlier. Jackson became a national hero and was elected seventh U.S. president in 1828. He was reelected in 1832. Engraved by H. B. Hall.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Death of General Pakenham
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving depicting the death of General Edward M. Pakenham at the Battle of New Orleans. Scene of the battle, with two men on horseback. Pakenham being carried by others in the center of the scene. Explosions over the American forces behind "Line Jackson" in the background.

Before leading the British forces at New Orleans, Pakenham fought against Napoleon in the Peninsular War (1807-1814), and took part in the Battles of Bussaco, Fuentes de Onoro, and Salamanca. In September 1814, Pakenham took over command of the British troops in North America. He was also the brother-in-law of Arthur Wellesley, First Duke of Wellington, who would later defeat Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo on June 18, 1815.

The band of Creeks known as the Red Sticks attacked the fort on August 30, 1813 resulting in the deaths or capture of approximately 250 settlers, militia, slaves, and Creeks who were loyal to the Americans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Death of General Pakenham scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, "Battle of New Orleans and Death of General Packenham [sic]." British and American forces clash as Pakenham falls mortally wounded from his horse. Abandoned cannon at right fallen soldiers and ladder on ground. From John Frost and W. Croome, "Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson."

Major-General The Honorable Sir Edward Michael Pakenham, commander of British troops at the Battle of New Orleans, was hit by grapeshot and died while being carried off the field, January 8, 1815. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither Pakenham nor U.S. General Andrew Jackson was aware that the Treaty of Ghent ended the War of 1812 two weeks earlier. Engraved by William Croome who also illustrated Crockett's Almanac.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Madison portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white steel engraving of James Madison (1751-1836), seated in plush chair with cabriole legs. He wears dark suit, cravat, stockings, and wig, and holds a document in one hand and what appears to be a handkerchief in the other. Facsimile signature. From The National Portrait Gallery of Eminent Americans. Engraving is after a portrait by Alonzo Chappel.

Madison, Father of the Constitution and Bill of Rights, was president during the War of 1812. Two years into the fighting, he and the government fled Washington City to avoid capture by the British. His wife Dolley saved the Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington before the British burned the White House and other public buildings. Madison was the last surviving Founding Father when he died in 1836.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Bust portrait of William Carroll (1788-1844) on silk. Carroll wears a dark coat and white cravat. "Possunt Quia Posse Videntur, Virtute Ac Labore" is printed above the image. "William Carroll, Esq." is printed below.

Governor of Tennessee, 1821-1827, 1829-1835. Carroll served in the Creek War (1813-1814) was seriously wounded at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend (March 27, 1814). He served as governor of Tennessee longer than any other. The silk portrait is possibly a campaign souvenir.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Captain James Lawrence portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Full-length portrait of Captain James Lawrence (1781-1813), in uniform, holding a saber, and seated in ship's interior. The engraving is from the original painting by Alonzo Chappel.

Lawrence was commander of the U.S.S. Hornet during the War of 1812. In 1813, he commanded the U.S.S. Chesapeake which lost its battle with the British ship H.M.S. Shannon. The Navy's motto Don't give up the ship is attributed to Lawrence who - though mortally wounded - gave the order to his officers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Andrew Jackson at the Battle of New Orleans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color print of Jackson rallying the troops as he rides a white horse. Two cannoneers fire on British redcoats who are charging the American position. A U.S. flag waves at center. This is a color version the engraving ID 26700.

Major-General Andrew Jackson commanded American militiamen and U.S. regulars during the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815). Sir Edward Pakenham, who was killed that day, led British forces. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither commander knew that a peace treaty had ended the War of 1812 two weeks earlier in Ghent (in present-day Belgium).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Henry Clay portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraved half-length portrait of Henry Clay, seated and facing front, wearing dark suit, vest, and cravat. His right hand rests on a table as he holds a document. Facsimile signature. Egraved by J. B. Longacre.

Clay was a U.S. Representative and U.S. Senator from Kentucky; he also served as Secretary of State. During the War of 1812, he was part of the War Hawk faction that agitated for war with Great Britain. As Speaker of the House, Clay molded the office into the powerful position it is today. When sectional issues rose after the War of 1812, Clay used his political influence to negotiate compromise between special interests. The Great Compromiser served the nation for almost 50 years.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Monroe portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraved image of James Monroe (1758-1831), seated in chair with cabriole legs. He wears a dark suit, trousers, and cravat and holds what appears to be a handkerchief in one hand. A large book is propped against a table leg. Facsimile signature.

James Monroe's presidency ushered in the "Era of Good Feelings" following the War of 1812. He was elected fifth president in 1816 and was reelected in 1820. Early in his first administration, the nationalism that characterized the Era of Good Feelings began to crack, and serious sectional issues grew. The Monroe Doctrine, which announced a hands-off policy to European powers seeking additional colonies in the Western Hemisphere, was effective well into the 20th century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oliver Hazard Perry portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving depicts Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry (1785-1819) seated on ship's deck. Perry wears U.S. Navy uniform of dark jacket and white trousers. A pistol is tucked in his belt. A large flag emblazoned with the words, "DON'T GIVE UP THE SHIP," waves in the background. Facsimile signature.

Perry was a U.S. naval officer who became a national hero when he defeated a British squadron in the Battle of Lake Erie (September 10, 1813) during the War of 1812. The victory gave the Americans full control of the strategic lake. Perry's report; to General William Henry Harrison stated simply, ""We have met enemy and they are ours.""

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sam Houston at Horseshoe Bend
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving of Sam Houston (1793-1863) in battle, holding a gun and sword. A soldier pulls an arrow out of Houston's leg. Several soldiers and Indian warriors lay dead. Indian warriors shooting arrows on the left. Image 9 of 16 in folder. From The Raven: A Biography of Sam Houston. Ensign Houston at To-Ho-Pe-Ka. (An engraving approved by Houston and first reproduced in 'Sam Houston and His Republic,' 1846)

Houston was seriously wounded at the Battle of Hoseshoe Bend (Tohopeka) on March 27, 1814. The American force, numbering 3,300 soldiers and friendly Cherokees and Creeks, overwhelmed about 1,000 of Chief Menawa's Red Stick Creek warriors. Around 800 Red Sticks were killed. The resulting Treaty of Fort Jackson ended the Creek War (1813-1814) and forced the Creek Nation to cede 23 million

Wife of Williamson County militia captain Thomas Wells who fought under Andrew Jackson in the Battle of New Orleans. During the War of 1812 women served on battlefields passing water to soldiers some disguised themselves and fought. They cooked, sewed, and served as nurse maids and scullery maids. Soldiers' wives could attend their husbands in camp through a lottery system.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of New Orleans scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, "The Battle of New Orleans," depicts Major-General Andrew Jackson atop a white horse and rallying his troops to defend an American position. Visible are a U.S. flag, a cannon and cannoneer, and British troops attacking the rampart. Bottom border is stained. Phillibrown, Thomas, engraver; and Dennis Malone Carter, artist

Jackson's American troops achieved an overwhelming victory against the British in the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815). The Treaty of Ghent had ended the War of 1812 two weeks ealier, but because of slow transatlantic communication, neither Jackson nor British commander Major-General Sir Edward Pakenham had learned the news.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: American Generals, War of 1812
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white patriotic lithograph depicts Generals Henry Dearborn, Winfield Scott, Andrew Jackson, William Henry Harrison, Jacob Jennings Brown, and Zebulon Pike. Image is decorated with cannon barrel, sabers, olive branches, and a U.S. flag.

Henry Dearborn (1751-1829) was a veteran of the Revolutionary War, but was a mediocre commander during the War of 1812. Jacob Jennings Brown (1775-1828) had successes in the North during the war that made him a hero. Winfield Scott (1796-1866) became the longest-serving American general in history. Andrew Jackson (1767-1845) was effective in the Creek Campaign and at the Battle of New Orleans. William Henry Harrison (1773-1841) commanded the Army of the Northwest during the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Lauderdale's Captain commission
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Document commissioning William Lauderdale as Captain in the 15th regiment of the Tennessee militia. Signed by Willie Blount. Includes seal of the State of Tennessee. To all who shall see these presents, Greeting: Know ye, that reposing special trust and confidence in the patriotism, valor, conduct, and fidelity of William Lauderdale of the county of Sumner, we do commission him Captain in the 15th regiment of militia of this state …"

William Lauderdale ( - 1838) was a captain of the 15th Tennessee Regiment. He fought under Andrew Jackson in the War of 1812. Later, as a Major he played an important role in the overthrow of the Creek Indians.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-colored patriotic engraving depicts bust image of General Andrew Jackson superimposed on U.S. flags, cannons, cannonballs, and an American eagle. Titled "Jackson/New Orleans Jany. 8th 1815."

Jackson commanded American forces at the Battle of New Orleans during the War of 1812. The battle had no effect on the war's outcome because word of the Treaty of Ghent (signed on December 24, 1814) had not yet reached America. Jackson came to national prominence was elected the 7th President of the United States. He served two terms (1829-1837).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "A View of Col. Johnson's Engagement with the Savages (commanded by Tecumseh) near the Moravian Town, October 5th, 1812 [sic]"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-colored woodcut depicts Colonel Richard Mentor Johnson defending himself against an Indian chief, American infantrymen firing on the enemy, a dismounted soldier engaging an Indian in hand-to-hand combat, a savage in the act of scalping a wounded drummer, cavalry pursuing retreating savages, and Tecumseh rallying his men. Prominent features are numbered. N.B. The word "savage" is used several times in the original illustration caption. N. Dearborn, engraver.

The Battle of Moraviantown was actually fought in 1813, not 1812. It is also known as the Battle of the Thames. A decisive U. S. victory there finalized American control of the Northwest. General William Henry Harrison commanded U.S. infantry and cavalry troops against a combined force of Indian Confederation warriors and the British. Several brigades of Kentucky militia supplemented Harrison's command. Colonel Johnson, a Kentucky War Hawk, may have been the one who shot and killed Tecumseh, the Shawnee chief who commanded the Confederation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Victory on Lake Erie
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A colored print of Commodore O.H. Perry's Victory on Lake Erie, 1813. A rowboat floats in between a fleet of ships. In the rowboat is an officer standing and holding a sword. Several men have oars. Additional information on back of print.

From the Franklin D. Roosevelt Naval Collection. (The Old Navy I, 1799-1815). The Battle of Lake Erie took place off the coast of Ohio on September 10, 1813. It was a major victory for the U. S. Navy fleet in the War of 1812, and it gave the Americans full control of the lake. Two well-known phrases originated during the battle. "We have met the enemy and they are ours," and "Don't give up the ship!"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edmund Pendleton Gaines
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraved portrait of Edmund Pendleton Gaines (1777-1849). Portrait from the waist up, Gaines is oriented towards his left at an angle. Military dress with a bar on each shoulder and embroidered collar.

Surveyed the roads from Nashville to Knoxville, 1801-1804, Gaines was also a General in the War of 1812 and Commissioner to Creek Indians in 1817. He fought in the Black Hawk War, Creek War, and Seminole Wars.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Straights of Niagara from Lake Erie to Lake Ontario
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Atlas etching shows key military sites along the Niagara River. From James Wilkinson, "Diagrams and Plans, Illustrative of the Principle Battles and Military Affairs, Treated of in Memoirs of My Own Times."

Controversial figure General James Wilkinson served in the Revolution and War of 1812. In 1787, he turned traitor and became a secret agent for Spain. After Thomas Jefferson purchased the Louisiana Territory from France, he appointed Wilkinson governor. Wilkinson was later accused of treason for his participation in Aaron Burr's conspiracy to separate Louisiana from the U.S. Their goal was to create an independent nation friendly to Spain. Wilkinson betrayed Burr and aided in his capture.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Andrew Jackson equestrian portrait
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-colored woodcut of General Andrew Jackson wearing blue coat, red sash, and gold epaulets. While Jackson rides his white horse, a fallen British soldier lies dead on the field.

Jackson commanded American forces at the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815) and achieved a resounding victory over the British. Neither British nor American commanders knew that a peace treaty ending the War of 1812 had been signed two weeks earlier. The battle made Jackson a national hero. Jackson was elected 7th President of the United States in 1828 and was reelected in 1832.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: John Sevier
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of John Sevier (1745-1815) in military uniform. Portrait from waist up. Right hand holds a sabor handle. The portrait was painted by Charles Willson Peale in 1790 and is now in the portait collection at the Tennessee State Museum.

John Sevier (1745-1815) served in the Revolutionary War, commanding troops at the Battle of King's Mountain. He fought many battles against the Native Americans during the early settlement of Tennessee. He was elected the first Governor of Tennessee. He was elected to Congress in 1811 and headed the Military Affairs Committee of the U.S. House of Representatives during the War of 1812.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Menawa
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek warrior Menawa in colorful Native-American clothing and a beaded bag.

Menawa was a half-blooded Creek warrior who supported the British during the War of 1812 and opposed the cession of tribal lands to the white people. He fought in support of the United States during the Seminole War, but was later forced to move west during the removal to Indian territory from 1836-1840. Menawa was also known as "Crazy War Hunter" because of his daring exploits during battle.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: History of the Indian tribes of North America, with biographical sketches and anecdotes of the principal chiefs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of Tallushatchee scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The image shows General Andrew Jackson cutting down Indians from atop a white horse. From John Frost and W. Croome, "Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson."

The battle took place on November 3, 1813, and was America's first victory against the Red Sticks in the Creek War (1813-1814). General John Coffee, a Tennessean, led the American forces who completely destroyed the village and killed many Creeks. A ten-month-old Creek orphan named Lincoya was taken from the battlefield to Fort Strother, where he caught the eye of General Andrew Jackson. The Jackson family later adopted the boy. David Crocket and Sam Houston also fought in the battle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William McIntosh
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Portrait of Creek chief William McIntosh wearing a cape over a checkered red vest and white shirt. His hand is on the hilt of a sword and his headdress is adorned with a single feather.

William McIntosh (or MacIntosh) was born in Georgia about 1785 of mixed ancestry, his father being a Scots trader and his mother a Creek Indian. He became a Creek chief at an early age and fought on the side of the Americans during the Creek War (1813-1814). His contiuned alliance with the U. S. government led to his death in 1825 by rival Creeks incensed at McIntosh's participation at the Indian Springs treaty which surrendred millions of acres to the Federal government.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Caring for the wounded after the Battle of New Orleans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Scene After the Battle of New Orleans," illustrates U.S. soldiers and militiamen caring for the wounded. At left, a British officer is lifted onto a stretcher. Background shows American parapets made of cotton bales. A U.S. flag waves in the background. From John Frost and William Croome, "Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson." Two uncolored versions, titled "General Jackson Relieving the Wounded British After the Battle," are also available.

Though it was fought after the Treaty of Ghent was signed, the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815) was a decisive victory for the United States in its war against Great Britain. Major-General Andrew Jackson commanded American troops, and British forces fought under the command of Major-General Sir Edward Pakenham. The War of 1812, also known as the ""Second American Revolution,"" brought greater American self-confidence and national pride.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of New Orleans scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, "The Battle of New Orleans," depicts Major-General Andrew Jackson atop a white horse and rallying his troops to defend an American position. Visible are a U.S. flag, a cannon and cannoneer, and British troops attacking the rampart. Bottom border is stained.

Jackson's American troops achieved an overwhelming victory against the British in the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815). The Treaty of Ghent had ended the War of 1812 two weeks ealier, but because of slow transatlantic communication, neither Jackson nor British commander Major-General Sir Edward Pakenham had learned the news.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of New Orleans scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Battle of New Orleans," depicts British redcoats attacking an American position. The Americans are firing muskets and a cannon at the enemy. From John Frost, "An Illuminated History of North America."

The Battle of New Orleans was fought between American and British forces on January 8, 1815. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither General Andrew Jackson nor British commander Sir Edward Pakenham was aware that a peace treaty had been signed two weeks earlier. The Treaty of Ghent (December 24, 1814) ended the War of 1812, so Jackson's overwhelming victory at New Orleans had no effect on the war's outcome.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Andrew Jackson addressing War of 1812 volunteers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, General Jackson Addressing the Volunteers, depicts Jackson in military uniform atop a white horse and with his arm raised. He appears to be making a motivational speech. Troops in blue, gold, red, and white uniforms stand in front of him. Image believed to be from a painting by S. F. Baker. From John Frost and William Croome, Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson.

Major-General Andrew Jackson commanded miltia and U.S. Regulars during the Creek War/War of 1812. His greatest victory of the Creek War was made at Horseshoe Bend (in present-day Alabama). His overwhelming success against the British at the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815) brought him to national attention. Jackson was elected president in 1828, and was reelected in 1832. Image is a color version of 29226.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, Battle of Enotichopco [sic], depicts an American officer rallying his troops while he rides a white horse. Infantrymen, wearing blue uniforms, stand with muskets ready for the Indian ambush. Other soldiers lie wounded. Two American flags wave at center. Image has a decorative border. From John Frost and W. Croome, Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson.

General Andrew Jackson and his militia army were ambushed by Red Stick Creeks while crossing Enitachopco Creek, January 24, 1814. Jackson's army repelled the attack by using artillery. The action took place during the Creek War (1813-1814).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Andrew Jackson addressing War of 1812 volunteers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, General Andrew Jackson Addressing the Volunteers, depicts Major-General Andrew Jackson atop white horse. He appears to be giving a motivational speech to the uniformed soldiers standing in front of him. Image believed to be from a painting by S. F. Baker engraving by J. Downes or Devereux. Possibly from John Frost and W. Croome, Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson (1848). See color engraving, DB 29226.

Major-General Andrew Jackson commanded miltia and U.S. Regulars during the Creek War/War of 1812. His greatest victory of the Creek War (1813-1814) was made at Horseshoe Bend (in present-day Alabama). His overwhelming success against the; British at the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815) brought him to national attention. The Battle of New Orleans took place after the Treaty of Ghent ended the War of 1812 (1812-1814). Jackson was elected president in 1828, and was reelected in 1832.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew Jackson and troops departing for New Orleans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Dearture of the Troops for New Orleans," shows Andrew Jackson and his mounted troops departing on horseback for New Orleans. Jackson, atop his white horse, speaks to an officer. Black and white version also in folder. From John Frost and W. Croome, "Pictorial Life of Ander Jackson." Possibly engraved by Devereux.

Kentuckians and Tennesseans comprised most of Jackson's militia. The Americans overwhelmed the British at the Battle of New Orleans on January 8, 1815. Because of slow transatlantic communication, neither side knew that the Treaty of Ghent had been signed two weeks earlier. Consequently, the battle had no effect on the war's outcome. Jackson came into national prominence and was elected 7th President in 1828. He was reelected in 1832.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Death of Colonel Robert Rennie scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving, "Death of Colonel Rennie," shows wounded British officer slumping forward. Behind him are his men. Armed Americans are firing at him from front. Decorative border around image. Black and white version also available. From John Frost and W. Croome, "Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson" (1848). Design by William Croome.

Colonel Robert Rennie, leading British infantrymen and fusiliers, died in an assault on Americans at the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815). The Treaty of Ghent, signed two weeks earlier, ended the War of 1812. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither the British nor Americans knew the war was over.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A one page letter written on May 8, 1814 and sent from Huntsville, Alabama. Coffee notes the vast amount and the value of country newly acquired as a result of the conquest of the Creek nation. He offers his services as a surveyor to lay out and survey these new lands.
Coffee surveyed the lands acquired by the U.S. after the Ceek War (1813-1814). He relocated to Alabama where he became a wealthy land-owner.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Jackson with the New Orleans Committee of Safety
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, "General Jackson Conferring with the Committee of Safety," depicts the American commander and a group of men standing around a covered table. Decorative border includes a flag and musket resting on a cannon and an American eagle perched atop two flags. From John Frost and William Croome, A Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson.

Before the battles of December 1814 and January 8, 1815, New Orleans citizens feared Jackson would burn the city rather than allowing the British to capture it. Committees of public safety were organized to encourage residents to protect their interests.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. Louis Cathedral in New Orleans
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of the Cathedral of St. Louis in New Orleans, Louisiana. Site of the victory celebration for Andrew Jackson at the conclusion of the campaign at New Orleans during the War of 1812.

On January 21, 1815, the city of New Orleans celebrated the victory of the American forces, led by General Andrew Jackson, over the British army during the campaign by the English to capture New Orleans. A grateful populace turned out to see Jackson crowned with a wreath of laurel outside this Catholic cathedral.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of the Lands in Mississippi ceded by the Chickasaws to the United States in 1832 and 1834
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map from the survey of Henry M. Lusher shows northern half of Mississippi and adjacent parts of Alabama, Tennessee and Arkansas. The Chickasaw-Choctaw boundary is shown beginning at the Mississippi River as well as Indian settlements, white settlements, roads and trails. The map also shows changes made to the Tennessee-Mississippi border.

In 1818 the Chickasaws gave up their claims to what is now West Tennessee and western Kentucky. In the early 1830s, the Chickasaws ceded over 6,000,000 acres of land in Mississippi in exchange for lands west of the Mississippi River. John Coffee, former general of the Tennessee volunteers during the War of 1812, represented the United States in many of the treaty negotiations with the South-eastern Tribes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scene of night action on December 23, 1814
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, "Night Action of the Twenty-third of December," shows American infantry marching, cannoneers firing an artillery piece, and a commander (probably General Andrew Jackson) on horseback. Decorative border includes a flag and musket resting on a cannon. Border is topped with an American eagle perched upon two flags. From John Frost and W. Croome, Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson.

The Battle of New Orleans was a series of clashes for control of the city with combat taking place between December 1814 and January 1815. General Andrew Jackson commanded an American force that overwhelmed the British enemy on January 8, 1815. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither side was aware that a peace treaty had been signed two weeks earlier.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jackson's Headquarters on New Orleans Battlefield
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of the plantation house that served as General Andrew Jackson's headquarters on the battlefield outside of New Orleans during the final phase of the War of 1812.

After the British forces landed south of New Orleans in late December 1814, General Andrew Jackson staved off the initial assault on the night of December 23. Afterwards, Jackson built a defensive line on the plains of Chalmette, a few miles south of the city of New Orleans. Jackson used the McCarty plantation house, depicted here, for his headquarters.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Octagon House, Washington, D.C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Etching of the three story front entry area of the Octagon House in Washington, D.C. Image is tinted red. Arched doorway at the top of four stairs. Above the door is an arched three section window. Four rectangle windows with sills. Tree in front. Octagon House, Washinton, D.C., where Jackson was entertained Nov. 15, 1815. Collection of the N.Y. Historical Society.

Andrew Jackson was entertained at this house in Washington, D.C. on November 15, 1815. The house was constructed between 1798 and 1800 for Colonel John Tayloe, a wealthy Virginia plantation owner. The architect of the U.S. Capitol, Dr. William Thornton , designed this structure as well. After the British burned the White House, Tayloe offered his home to President and Mrs. Madision. Madision signed the Treaty of Ghent ending the War of 1812 at Octagon House.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tohopeka (Horseshoe Bend), Tallapoosa River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sepia aerial photograph of Tohopeka (Horseshoe Bend), Tallapoosa River, Alabama.

The Battle of Horseshoe Bend (Tohopeka) took place on March 27, 1814, during the Creek War. At a bend in the Tallapoosa River in central Alabama, American militiamen under General Andrew Jackson defeated the Red Sticks, a hostile Creek faction.; Red Sticks objected to Euro-American encroachments on their land and the assimilation and intermarriage with whites. The battle was a decisive victory for the Americans. The Treaty of Fort Jackson forced Creek cession of approximately 23 million acres.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from John Coffee written to Samuel Houston
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A four-page letter written from Florence, Alabama, on April 25, 1828. Coffee answers Sam Houston's inquiry regarding the accusation by some that the Battle of Horseshoe Bend was a "cold blooded massacre." Coffee defends General Andrew Jackson's conduct there and throughout the war. Coffee mentions "Lincoyer," the infant Creek whom Jackson later adopted, and he states that the child's mother had been unavoidably killed at Tallushatchee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight woodcut “coffin handbills” compiled in a pamphlet known as “Monumental Inscriptions.” Each illustration is in a tombstone shape with epitaphs.

The “coffin handbills” were distributed by the anti-Jacksonians during the presidential campaign of 1828. Their purpose was to smear Jackson’s character. The handbills brought attention to the militiamen Jackson ordered executed during the Creek War and War of 1812: John Harris, David Hunt, Edward Linsey, Jacob Webb, Henry Lewis, David Morrow, and John Woods. Pamphlet includes memorials to six militiamen and one to the memory of John Woods's mother.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On this two-sided "List of Men left in my charge Sick. Lame & wound out with fatigue," Dr. William Lawrence reports sixty-four unfit men. List includes not only their names, but it identifies their militia companies. Several deaths are noted at bottom of page 2.

William Pitt Lawrence was Surgeon, 3rd Regiment, Tennessee Militia, during the War of 1812. The regiment was probably returning to Tennessee after the Battle of New Orleans (January 8, 1815). Their camp was eleven miles from Allen's Ferry on Bogue Chitto.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Manuscript related to the presentation of a Congressional Gold Medal to Andrew Jackson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five pages of handwritten comments concern the presentation of a Congressional Gold Medal to Andrew Jackson. Includes complimentary remarks by President James Madison and Governor Isaac Shelby. It is uncertain whether Jackson himself wrote the reply.

The thanks of Congress and the medal were awarded on February 27, 1815, in recognition of Jackson’s defense of New Orleans during the War of 1812. The Battle of New Orleans was fought after the Treaty of Ghent was signed, but because of slow transatlantic communications British and American commanders had not yet received word the war was over. Jackson was popular among militiamen who dubbed him “tough as old hickory wood.” The battle catapulted "Old Hickory" to the status of national hero.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from H. E. Pace to Governor Hill McAlister regarding rural electrification
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from H. E. Pace to Governor McAlister inquiring about rural electrification for the communities of Thomasville, Oak Plains, and Fredonia, Tennessee.

By the 1930s, nearly 90% of the U. S. population living in urban areas had electricity while only 10% of the rural population did. To address this problem, the Roosevelt Administration created the Rural Electrification Administration [REA] in 1935. By 1939, the efforts of the REA, Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA), etc. had increased the number of rural households with electricity to 25%.

The firm was formed by Thomas Marr and Joseph Holman in 1913. Among the buildings in Nashville designed by the firm are: Belmont Theater, Sulphur Dell baseball park, U.S. Post Office (now the Frist Center for the Visual Arts), Tennessee Home for Feeble Minded Persons (now Clover Bottom Developmental Center), and Tennessee State Supreme Court. The firm also designed many of the buildings at the Tennessee School for the Deaf in Knoxville. This latter project was of special significance to Marr since he was deaf himself and graduated from the school in 1884.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the Blue Eagle means to you and how you can get it
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: National Recovery Administration (NRA) broadside informing employers how they may obtain a blue eagle to signify their compliance with the President's Reemployment Agreement. It also contains the provisions of the President's Reemployment Agreement.

The National Recovery Administration (NRA) was a New Deal program created by the National Industrial Recovery Act (NIRA) in 1933. Its goal was to help businesses and workers by setting minimum wages, maximum weekly work hours, and by fixing prices. The NIRA was declared unconstitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1935 in A.L.A. Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States, 295 U.S. 495. The NRA was dissolved as a result. The blue eagle logo of the NRA is, perhaps, one of the most iconic symbols of the New Deal. The Philadelphia Eagles, of the National Football League, were named in honor of the NRA logo.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The critter he got from those Washington Horse Traders
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Editorial cartoon by Jack Knox showing a farmer attempting to plow his field with a comically undersized mule/horse. It is titled, "The Critter He Got From Those Washington Horse Traders." It is probably a commentary on the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Jack Knox (1910-1985) was a cartoonist for the Evening Tennessean (Nashville), the Memphis Commercial Appeal, and Nashville Banner newspapers.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration (AAA) was created after the passage of the Agricultural Adjustment Act in May 1933. The AAA attempted to aid farmers by raising crop and livestock prices through the payment of subsidies to reduce crop production and to kill excess livestock. In January 1936, the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1933 was ruled unconstitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court in the case United States v. Butler, 297 U.S. 1. The Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938 rectified the portions of the 1933 act which the Supreme Court had declared unconstitutional.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Bluntly, He'd Rather Not Have that Bozo Introduced"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Editorial cartoon by Jack Knox depicting President Franklin D. Roosevelt attempting to introduce the "food subsidy program" to the U.S. Congress. The man depicting Congress is shown replying, "Sorry--But I ain't makin' any new acquaintances." The cartoon is titled, "Bluntly, He'd Rather Not Have that Bozo Introduced." The cartoon is possibly referring to the creation of the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation.

Jack Knox (1910-1985) was a cartoonist for the Evening Tennessean (Nashville), the Memphis Commercial Appeal, and Nashville Banner newspapers.
The Federal Surplus Relief Corporation (FSRC) was created in October 1933. Working in conjunction with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, it purchased surplus food commodities and distributed them to the unemployed. Its name was changed to the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation in November 1935. The current federal food assistance and school lunch programs are an outgrowth of the creation of the FSRC.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: President Franklin D. Roosevelt speaking at the dedication of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: President Roosevelt stands at a bunting-covered podium that holds several microphones. He faces right as if he is speaking to the guests seated behind him.

Located in East Tennessee and western North Carolina, the park was officially established in 1934 and dedicated in 1941. Men from the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) and Works Progress Administration (WPA) played a significant role in creating the park. They built hiking trails and fire watchtowers and improved infrastructure. Not all Tennesseans were happy about the park. Bit by bit the federal government purchased the land from farmers and mountaineers--often at less than acceptable prices--who were evicted.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Old Blue in a scene from "Wild River"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white studio photograph shows an elderly African American man talking to an older gray-haired white woman. The man, in overalls, holds a hound on a leash. The two stand in front of a movie-set shack. Three black farm hands are seen in background. Children play in foreground.

The motion-picture film "Wild River" was released in 1960 by Twentieth Century-Fox. It tells the story of the Garth family and their farm hands who are forced to leave their river island as the Tennessee Valley Authority floods their land. Blue was not for sale, but Sam would give him to Miss Ella if she wanted to stay. The TVA was created in 1933 to manage natural resources in the Tennessee River Valley. It brought low-cost hydroelectricity to the valley people, improved river navigation, and controlled flooding.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mississippian skeletal remains
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of skeletal remains.

The WPA (Works Progress Administration, later Work Projects Administration) launched archaeological investigations in 1935 to provide jobs during the Depression. Most of the excavations were done in the Southeast, including Tennessee. These scientific investigations contributed to a greater understanding of diverse American cultures, including Mississippian ones. The Cumberland River Valley around Nashville is particularly rich in these types of burial sites. Photograph possibly taken in Humphreys County.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: On the cuff
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Red and khaki front book cover for Gleason L. Archer's "On the Cuff" is decorated with a circular logo in the style of a wax seal. Printed inside the seal is an extended left arm, or "Uncle Sam's 'Left Wing,'" as the coat sleeve is labeled. On the cuff is written "338 Billions/Baby Will Pay." A summary of the book's contents is printed at the bottom.

The New Deal had many detractors who felt that President Roosevelt's policies were socialistic. Importantly, they feared the creation of a welfare state and the destruction of free enterprise and Jeffersonian democracy. In his first 100 days, FDR sent a record number of bills to Congress designed to alleviate the effects of the Depression. Some Americans, like Archer, believed he went too far, and they questioned the constitutionality of several programs. "On the Cuff" is a conservative indictment of FDR's policies.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Political cartoon, "The Destiny of a Nation"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Editorial cartoon shows Uncle Sam standing in a hand representing the Supreme Court. Uncle Sam holds a large scroll labeled "New Deal." The cartoon is pasted in a scrapbook signed by Tennessean cartoonist Joe Parrish, but the cartoon identifies the artist as Cross.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal provided plenty of fodder for editorial cartoonists. Early on conservatives were alarmed by what they considered the establishment of a welfare state. Conservative justices struck down a number of FDR's signature "alphabet agencies," including the AAA (Agricultural Adjustment Act) and the NRA (National Recovery Act).
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; Political cartoons
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Cross

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Political cartoon, "The Nation's Champion Recovery Producer"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A cow symbolizing the AAA (Agricultural Adjustment Act) stands by milk cans touting the success of the program. The first can is labeled, "Increased Farm Income," and the middle one is labeled, "Business and Industrial Gains through Re-Establishment of Agriculture's Purchasing Power." The cow feeds on the processing tax used to help pay the farmers. An obese industrialist, pointing out the cow to a man representing the Supreme Court, says, "I want her killed so we won't have to feed her."

In the first 100 days of his presidency, Franklin D. Roosevelt introduced a record number of proposals designed to ease the Depression. Among the first was the AAA. Its intent was to raise depressed farm prices to pre-World War I levels. The money to pay the farmers for cutting back production by about 30 percent was raised by a tax on companies that bought agricultural products and processed them into food and clothing. The Supreme Court nixed the Act, declaring it unconstitutional. The cartoonist, Joe Parrish, was working for the Nashville Tennessean at the time.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; Political cartoons
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Parrish, Joseph Lee, 1905-1989

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Political cartoon, "Certainly, We'll Shoulder Our Part"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joe Parrish political cartoon shows tall Uncle Sam carrying an oversize bundle labeled, "Uncle Sam's Relief Burden." Standing next to him is a tiny image of President Franklin D. Roosevelt holding a much smaller bag labeled, "Our Local Community Chest Duty." The cartoon is one of many in a scrapbook kept by young Henry McRaven. Parrish signed the opening page.

Joe Parrish, a native Tennessean, was a political cartoonist at the Nashville Banner, Nashville Tennessean, and Chicago Tribune. During the 1930s, Parrish both praised and parodied New Deal programs. At the Tribune, Parrish was one of three native Tennessee cartoonists, the others being Carey Orr and Daniel E. Holland. Because of their acerbic caricatures, the publisher referred to them as "the terrible three from Tennessee."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Publick Works Administration logo
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frontispiece for "America Builds: The Record of the PWA," is printed in black and white. The logo takes the form of a compass. A working man is superimposed on the letters "PWA" and set inside an industrial cog. Extending from the north is a factory scene with smoke stacks and electrical power lines. From the other directions are axes and plumbs.

The Public Works Administration (PWA) was one of the first of the New Deal "alphabet agencies" intended to alleviate the effects of the Depression. It was created as part of the National Industrial Recovery Act in 1933. In cooperation with state, county, and city governments, the PWA spent $4 billion constructing 70 per cent of the nation's new educational buildings; 65 per cent of its new courthouses, city halls, and sewage plants; 35 per cent of its new public health facilities; and 10 per cent of all new bridges, roads, and subways.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; United States. Public Works Administration

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WPA bookmobile
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mimeographed page contains two original black and white photographs. The top photo is of a woman and two children looking at books in a mobile library. It is identified as the "WPA bookmobile in the Watts Barr [sic] Dam Defense Area covering Rhea, Rhone [sic], Loudon, and Meigs Counties." The bottom photo shows a WPA mobile library parked outside Stewart's Cash Grocery. Children wait in line. The truck is identified as the WPA bookmobile sponsored by the Nashville Public Library. These pictures, between pages 7 and 8, are stapled to the page.

The Work Projects Administration (WPA, formerly Works Progress Administration) infused funds into many libraries. In rural areas of Kentucky and the Appalachians, librarians often used horses as mobile libraries. Marshall Stewart was the Tennessee state supervisor for the Library Service Program. The photos are from the annual report issued for 1940-1941.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rising water, flood of 1937
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph shows rising floodwaters. In the water can be seen a partially submerged building and a crane. At left is a sandbag levee just above a railroad track. A water tank and electrical power lines are in the background. Written at bottom left is (G630P-105) (2-5-37-2P).

In 1937 the Cumberland, Tennessee, Ohio, and Mississippi Rivers flooded to create the worst disaster in American history to that date. In January 21.24 inches (156 trillion tons) of rain fell in a 12-state region. Governor Gordon Browning activated the Tennessee National Guard because of record flooding in East and Middle Tennessee. Volunteers, state highway patrolmen, WPA workers, volunteers, and the Red Cross helped with sandbagging, providing for refugees, and building temporary housing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; Floods; Natural disasters
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Photo Section, 105th Observation Squadron

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sandbag preparation, Cumberland River flood
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of a soldier walking past a sandbag wall placed next to railroad tracks. The soldier wears a campaign hat with his uniform. In the background are electrical poles and period automobiles.

The photo was probably taken in Nashville during the historic flood of 1937. The Tennessee National Guard and Works Progress Administration (WPA) contributed to the attempt to protect Nashville from flooding. WPA workers built makeshift levees and flood walls, and helped care for refugees. The 105th Observation Squadron (Tennessee National Guard), which took the picture, was re-designated the 105 Airlift Squadron in 1992.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Plantation South, 1934-1937
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Umber paper cover of "The Plantation South, 1934-1937," an illustrated research monograph of the Work Projects Administration (WPA), shows drawings of an idealized plantation house and what could be a sharecropper's cabin. The booklet is identified as Research Monograph XXII.

The monograph analyzed data and reported on changes in planation organization and operation in the South. It found that of the 246 plantations surveyed, both landlords and tenants improved their financial status, though sharecroppers' net income averaged only about $400 per family. The study found that rural Southern folk suffered widespread unemployment and underemployment. In 1937, President Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed a commission that concluded the South was economic problem one.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: National Recovery Administration poster
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small red, white, and blue makeshift poster advertising the National Recovery Administration. Surrounding the blue eagle logo are the words, NRA MEMBER/U.S./WE DO OUR PART. The printed poster is glued to the backside of a color mountain scene.

At President Franklin D. Roosevelt's suggestion, Congress created the NRA in 1933. It was intended to boost business recovery by implementing fair trade practices. Roosevelt hoped it would ease unemployment, create minimum wages, and allow for collective bargaining. The NRA was short-lived. The Supreme Court invalidated it in 1935. Businesses were encouraged to display the "Blue Eagle" emblem in their windows.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps Company 1473, Camp Evan Shelby
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph shows three rows of men wearing CCC uniforms. At the center of the first row, an enlistee holds a small dog, named "skipper", presumably the company mascot. The picture was taken in a forest clearing.

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC, 1933-1942) was one of the "alphabet agencies" created by the New Deal to ease the effects of the Great Depression. The CCC provided economic relief for unemployed young men by putting them to work on conservation projects. They built roads, bridges, state parks and forests, hiking trails, fire towers, and other public works. More than seventy thousand Tennesseans served in the CCC. In 1937, the number of camps in Tennessee peaked at forty-six.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Negley guard tower
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of four men standing at the end of the parapet walk (allure) of a timber fort. Allure leads to a guard tower. Smoggy city in background.

The Works Progress Administration (WPA) was created in 1935 as a Depression relief measure. For an average salary of $41.57 a month, WPA employees built bridges, roads, public buildings, public parks, and airports. By the time it was dissolved in 1943, the WPA had employed 8.5 million people. In the 1930s workers restored Fort Negley in Nashville. The Federal fortification was originally built in 1862, much of it with slave labor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newspaper advertisement
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clipping. Front-page editorial letter to U.S. Representative Clarence W. Turner protesting the placement of a Negro Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) camp at Montgomery Bell Park. The writer says the Army's intention to place black enlistees at the park "will cause no end of trouble and probably bloodshed."

At the time of his death in 1939, Clarence Wyly Turner was a Democratic representative from Tennessee's Sixth Congressional District. J. E. Reeder was editor of the "The New Idea." African American CCC camps often were not welcome in white-populated areas of the South. Around 200,000 black men served in the CCC. The New Idea was published in Burns, Dickson County, Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Telegram to Governor Hill McAlister
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Western Union telegram protests the placement of a junior CCC camp at "my little home town," Pikeville, Tennessee.

Samuel Davis McReynolds was a member of the U.S. Congress, 1923-1939. A Democrat, he represented Tennessee's Third Congressional District. The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was established in 1933 as a means of providing jobs for young men from relief families. The enlistees planted trees; built bridges, parks, and roads; cultivated forests and constructed fire towers; and drained swamps. Draining swamps went a long way in preventing malaria. The "Tree Army" employed around 200,000 black men during the Depression.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Telegram, Walter Chandler to Governor Hill
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Western Union telegram protests the placement of a Negro Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) camp at Collierville, Shelby County. Collierville had been designated for a white camp, and the change is "very embarrassing to me." It is signed Walter Chandler.

Walter Chandler was a member of Congress and served in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1935 to 1940. A Democrat, he represented Tennessee's Ninth Congressional District. The CCC was established in 1933 as a means to provide jobs for young men from relief families. Enlistees planted trees; built bridges, parks, and roads; cultivated forests and constructed fire towers; and drained swamps. Draining swamps went a long way toward preventing malaria. Around 200,000 "colored" men served in the CCC.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fire tower, Bledsoe State Forest
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of a 60-foot steel fire tower and a wooden ranger's station. An automobile, identified as crew transportation, is parked outside the station. Image is pasted on a loose-leaf page.

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was one of the first of Franklin D. Roosevelt's "alphabet agencies" designed to ease the effects of the Depression. The CCC was a relief agency that promoted environmental conservation and intended to build good citizens through vigorous, disciplined outdoor labor. It built roads and hiking trails, state parks and forests, fire towers, and other public works. Soil conservation and reforestation were CCC signature efforts. According to the Times-Free Press, the men of "District C" Company 1466 were sent to a work site with no telephone, no electricity, no water source or a tank for storing water, and the wiring for an electric generator was incomplete.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Works Progress Administration schedule of hourly wages
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mimeographed WPA form listing occupational titles of skilled labor, hourly wages, hours of work, and monthly earnings. Occupations include artist, blacksmith, Braille proofreader, forelady and foreman (they earned the same), glazier, librarian, musician, photographer, plasterer, roofer, stone mason, teacher, terrazzo layer, and welder.

The Works Progress Administration (WPA, later Work Projects Administration) offered work to the unemployed on an unprecedented scale by spending money on a wide variety of programs, including highways and building construction, slum clearance, reforestation, and rural rehabilitation. A gigantic undertaking, it was inevitably attended by confusion, waste, and political favoritism, yet the "pump-priming" effect stimulated private business during the Depression and inaugurated reforms that states had been unable to subsidize. During 1935-1943, the WPA employed some 8.5 million people. (Information from Indiana University's online WPA exhibit)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fort Negley
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kodachrome slide shows a guard tower at the corner of a timber structure identified as Fort Negley. A stacked-stone fence stands at right. A path travels between the fort and fence. Stamped on the slide encasement is the number 89. A stamp identified the collection as T.H.S. AC. 678.

Fort Negley was a Federal fortification in Nashville at the time of the Civil War. According to historian Carroll Van West the polygonal fort was built with timber, stone, and dirt in 1862 largely by African American labor. During the Battle of Nashville (1864) the garrison included troops of the USCT. Following the war the fort was used as a Ku Klux Klan gathering place. The Works Progress Administration (WPA) restored the structure in 1936-1937.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Political cartoon, "The Eagle's Brood"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: National Recovery Administration (NRA) eagle atop nest of hatchlings. They are labeled "Employment," "Wage Increases," "Business Revival," and "Improved Working Conditions."

The recognizable Blue Eagle was the symbol of the National Recovery Administration (NRA), created in 1933. The NRA was one of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal "alphabet agencies" created to ease the effects of the Depression. It was intended to stimulate business recovery through fair practices. Its goal was to reduce unemployment, establish minimum wages and maximum hours, and guarantee the right of labor to bargain collectively. Some considered the NRA socialistic, and though it was invalidated by the Supreme Court in 1935, many of its provisions were included in later legislation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wilson Dam on the Tennessee River
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Stereographic image of an open dam.

Construction of Wilson Dam began in 1918 and was completed in 1924. It was named for President Woodrow Wilson. The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) acquired the dam in 1933, and it is one of nine in the TVA system. Its original purpose was to provide hydroelectric power to local nitrate plants and improve navigation of the Tennessee River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Invitation to the Innauguration of President Franklin D. Roosevelt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Franklin D. Roosevelt inviting Governor Hill McAlister to the Presidential Inauguration. Official invitation from the Inauguration Committee to Governor Hill McAlister.

Hill McAlister was born in Nashville in 1875. He was elected Governor of Tennessee in 1932, and re-elected in 1934. He did not seek re-election in 1936. He died in 1959. Franklin Delano Roosevelt (FDR) was elected President of the United States in 1932 and re-elected in 1936, 1940, and 1944. He died in office in 1945. Taking office during the Great Depression, he instituted the New Deal, a panoply of government programs intended to lift the country out of the Great Depression.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An Act Creating the Rural Electrification Authority of Tennessee...
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Text of Senate Bill 1000, An Act Creating the Rural Electrification Authority of Tennessee for the Purpose of Promoting and Encouraging the Fullest Possible Use of Electric Energy in the State by Making Electric Energy Available to Certain Inhabitants of the State the Lowest Cost Consistent with Sound Economy and Prudent Management; Authorizing the Authority to Sell and Distribute Electric Energy and to Construct or Otherwise Acquire a System or Systems for the Generation, Transmission and Distribution of Electric Energy to Carry Out the Purpose of This Act; Providing for the Rights, Powers and Duties of the Authority; Authorizing and Regulating the Issuance of Bonds by the Authority; and Providing for the Payment of Such Bonds and the Rights of the Holders Thereof.

By the 1930s, nearly 90% of the U. S. population living in urban areas had electricity while only 10% of the rural population did. To address this problem, the Roosevelt Administration created the Rural Electrification Administration [REA] in 1935. By 1939, the efforts of the REA, Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA), etc. had increased the number of rural households with electricity to 25%.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from P. Warner Frazer to Captain George A. Frazer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Frazer's four-page letter (with postal cover) to Dear Father describes his work and accommodations in a Louisiana CCC camp. Everything about the camp is very pleasant, and the men share two to a tent. Tents have wooden floors and gas heat. We have seen quite a few chameleons. They are very cute. They look like ordinary little lizards but they change color.... [chameleons] have a way of blowing out their throat when they get excited. It opens up just like a fan. Includes writer's primitive drawing of a chameleon. Postal cover included as fifth page.

Frazer was assigned to CCC Camp Urania Forest (No. 1492), near Olla, La. The Civilian Conservation Corps (1933-1942) was one of the alphabet agencies created by the New Deal to combat the Great Depression. The CCC provided economic relief for young men by putting them to work on projects to conserve and develop the country's natural resources.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Telegram from Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, to Governor Hill McAlister
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Telegram from Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, to Governor McAlister outlining the organizational hierarchy of the various district and state recovery boards.

The National Recovery Administration (NRA) was a New Deal program created by the National Industrial Recovery Act (NIRA) in 1933. Its goal was to help businesses and workers by setting minimum wages, maximum weekly work hours, and by fixing prices. The NIRA was declared unconstitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1935 in A.L.A. Schechter Poultry Corp. v. United States, 295 U.S. 495. The NRA was dissolved as a result. The blue eagle logo of the NRA is, perhaps, one of the most iconic symbols of the New Deal. The Philadelphia Eagles, of the National Football League, were named in honor of the NRA logo.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Telegram from Robert W. Johnson, Chicopee Corporation, to Governor Hill McAlister
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Telegram from Robert W. Johnson, President, Chicopee Corporation, to Governor McAlister regarding the National Recovery Administration's code of competition for the textile industry. Johnson does not object to the minimum wage in the code, but to limit on the number of hours a mill's machinery may operate. He argues that the limits will shift textile production from mills in the South to closed mills in the North. He urges Governor McAlister to protest against limiting hours of operation for mills.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Henion Patterson to Governor Hill McAlister
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two-page penciled letter (front and back) related to writer's discharge from the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC). Patterson wants to rejoin the CCC and explains that he had been working on a Jack Hammer when I was Discharged _____ that Dust got Down my throuth [throat] and thay Discharged on that a count. I am a Demercratt....

Henion Patterson was an African American from Anderson County at the time he wrote this letter. The CCC was established in 1933 as a means of providing jobs for unemployed young men from relief families. The enlistees planted trees; built bridges, parks, and roads; cultivated forests; constructed fire towers; and drained swamps. Draining swamps went a long way in preventing malaria. The Tree Army employed around 200,000 black men during the Depression.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps crew working in Pickett State Forest
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of four men raking a forest floor. All are wearing hats. The photo is pasted on loose-leaf paper.

Formed in March 1933, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was among the first of Franklin D. Roosevelt's alphabet agencies designed to ease the effects of the Depression. The relief agency promoted environmental conservation and intended to build good citizens through vigorous, disciplined outdoor labor. The CCC built roads, hiking trails, state parks and forests, fire towers, bridges, and other public works. Soil conservation and reforestation were CCC signatures. The �Tree Army� relieved rural unemployment and keep youth out of trouble.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence between Governor Hill McAlister and President Franklin D. Roosevelt about state rural electrification legislation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from President Roosevelt stating that the Legal Division of the Public Works Administration will assist Governor McAlister with drafting legislation to allow municipalities to participate in public works projects. President Roosevelt's letter also includes suggestions for legislation revising municipal financing laws. Carbon copy of a response from Governor McAlister to President Roosevelt about passing legislation in the Tennessee General Assembly to foster rural electrification. He requests that Secretary of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes, provide sample language for such legislation.

The Works Progress Administration (WPA) was a New Deal program designed to put unemployed Americans back to work. Between 1935 and its termination in 1943, the WPA employed approximately 8 million workers. In Tennessee, the WPA built roads, sewer systems, bridges, waterways, dams, viaducts, and overpasses. It also built major airports in Memphis, Chattanooga, Knoxville, Nashville, and at the Tri-Cities of Bristol, Johnson City, and Kingsport.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps Company 1473, Camp Evan Shelby
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photographs shows three rows of men wearing CCC uniforms. At the center of the first row, an enlistee holds a small dog, named skipper, presumably the company mascot. The picture was taken in a forest clearing.

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC, 1933-1942) was one of the alphabet agencies created by the New Deal to ease the effects of the Great Depression. The CCC provided economic relief for unemployed young men by putting them to work on conservation projects. They built roads, bridges, state parks and forests, hiking trails, fire towers, and other public works. More than seventy thousand Tennesseans served in the CCC. In 1937, the number of camps in Tennessee peaked at forty-six.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Correspondence between Governor Hill McAlister and President Franklin D. Roosevelt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Telegram from Governor McAlister to President Roosevelt recommending the continuation of the Farm Debt Adjustment program. Letter from President Roosevelt replying to McAlister's telegram.

The Farm Debt Adjustment program was an outgrowth of the Farm Credit Act of 1933 and the creation of the Farm Credit Administration that same year. The goal was to lower foreclosure rates by allowing farmers to refinance their mortgages at below-market interest rates and make payments over a longer period of time.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Workers installing bronze doors at Davidson County Courthouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two workers installing the doors of the Davidson County Courthouse. The figures on the doors represent (from L to R): Loyalty, Law, Justice, and Wisdom. 2 copies in folder.

The Davidson County Courthouse was a Public Works Administration project and was built from August 1936-December 1937. Each of the 6 2-story bronze doors at the main entrance has a symbolic figure on it representing: Courage, Loyalty, Law, Justice, Security, and Wisdom. The windows over the doors have a figure of a lawgiver sandblasted into the glass (King John of England, Moses, and Justinian). A blindfolded Justice holding scales is in the window over the rear entrance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: National Youth Administration workshop
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified workshop, showing a sign reading "National Youth Administration Work Shop Youth Work Experience."

The National Youth Administration (NYA) was created in June 1935 through an executive order by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. As part of the Works Progress Administration (WPA), the NYA offered vocational classes to young fulltime students and employed many others in part-time jobs. NYA youth built shops and vocational buildings in twenty-three of Tennessee's counties and gyms and recreational buildings in thirteen others. The NYA was abolished in 1943 when Congress refused to grant it further funding.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Water tank built by CCC at Pickett State Forest
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of two men at a stone-clad water tank built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in Pickett State Forest.

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) did the initial development of the Pickett State Forest site following the donation of the 12,000 acres to the state by Stearns Coal and Lumber Company in 1933. Between 1934 and 1942, hiking trails, cabins, a lodge, a ranger station, and a 12-acre lake were put in place. CCC employees quarried native sandstone from the area to use in building construction. The Park appears on the National Register of Historic Places.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Erosion in Fayette County, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Log cabin with side chimney sits atop a hill. It is surrounded by massive hillside erosion.

Drought continued to be a problem in the South throughout the 1930s. Farmers had overproduced crops to the detriment of the soil (and prices), and erosion affected farmers' production ability. Consequently, many farms were foreclosed on during the Great Depression. The FDR administration first attempted to alleviate farm troubles through the Agricultural Adjustment Act, but the Supreme Court nixed it. Congress replaced it with farm-lending programs and instruction in soil conservation methods.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Old log schoolhouse in Great Smoky Mountains National Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man wearing a white shirt and a tie leans against a log structure. Two windows can be seen at his left. The logs are wide-cut with dovetail notches, and the roof is shake.

Possibly the Little Greenbrier School located in what is now the Great Smoky Mountains National Park (GSMNP). The park was built with the assistance of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), a New Deal agency designed to provide jobs for young Depression-era men on relief.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps (C.C.C.) boys spreading sand on the beach at the Cumberland Homesteads State Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of twelve CCC workers spreading sand with shovels near the Byrd Creek Dam in Cumberland Mountain State Park.

The Civilian Conservation Corps was a public relief program created by Congress in 1937. It provided jobs for unemployed young men and promoted environmental conservation. One of the first New Deal programs, the CCC built roads, homes, and fire towers. Its reforestation projects replaced trees on lands that had been overfarmed or cleared by loggers. The CCC vastly improved state and national park infrastructure.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scene from "Wild River" shows "Garth Island"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a ferry (at left) on the bank of a bend in the river. Two wires attached to an overhead guide are for towing the ferry across the river. At the right side of the photo is an island.

At right, the fictional "Garth Island," reached by a current-pushed ferry. This location, at Coon Denton, a few miles up the Hiwassee River from Calhoun, Tennessee, was chosen to represent typical bottomland before the TVA dam was closed. The movie "Wild River" (1960) brought attention to the thousands of Tennesseans who had been forced to abandon their homes and land to make way for the Tennessee Valley Authority. Directed by Elia Kazan, the movie starred Montgomery Clift and Lee Remick.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial photograph of Knoxville airport
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial view of the Knoxville airport.

The Works Progress Administration (WPA) was a New Deal program designed to put unemployed Americans back to work. Between 1935 and its termination in 1943, the WPA employed approximately 8 million workers. In Tennessee, the WPA built roads, sewer systems, bridges, waterways, dams, viaducts, and overpasses. It also built airports in Memphis, Chattanooga, Jackson, Clarksville, Knoxville, Nashville, Bristol, and numerous other Tennessee cities.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Civilian Conservation Corps Camp-TVA-45-Company 444
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic group photograph labeled Civilian Conservation Corps Camp-TVA-45-Company-494 Norris, Tenn. Officers listed: P. R. Chaplin, D. R. Griner, W. D. May, W. C. Cobb, W. T. Davis. The uniformed men are standing outdoors in front of long barracks.

The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) was created in 1933 and was one of the first New Deal projects. It was designed to ease the Depression by creating jobs and to promote environmental conservation. Young men who enlisted in the ""Tree Army""; built roads, fire towers, bridges and canals, and planted trees for reforestation and erosion control. By 1942, the CCC had built 800 parks and planted 3 billion trees. The program was one of the most popular of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal programs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Governor Gordon Browning giving a speech
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A Tribune wirephoto of Governor Gordon Browning giving a speech. The typed caption on the reverse reads: ""Gov. Gordon Browning gestures vigorously in speech delivered in camp of Shelby County enemy, E. H. Crump.""; Accompanied by related clippings.

Browning was the Governor of Tennessee from 1937-1939 and again from 1949-1953. Edward Hull ""Boss"" Crump was the mayor of Memphis (1910-1915) and a U.S. Representative (1931-1935). He also ran the Memphis political machine and was influential in state; politics for much of the 20th Century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Presentation of Joe Parrish cartoon to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sepia-tone photograph of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Eleanor Roosevelt seated in the back seat of an open-air automobile. A large crowd surrounds them. Insert cartoon touts FDR and the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).

Joseph L. Parrish retired as chief editorial cartoonist for the Chicago Tribune in 1970. A native of Tennessee, he began his career at the [Nashville] Tennessean in 1929 and was nationally known for his political caricatures. He moved to the Tribune seven; years later. The Roosevelts visited the James K. Polk tomb, The Hermitage, Fisk and Vanderbilt Universities, and a Madison school during their stop. They also appeared in Knoxville and inspected Norris Dam.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: WPA workers at Standing Stone State Park
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Group of men, all wearing overalls, in front of the 12-foot rock that gave the state park its name. At front row, right, a man holds a puppy. Photograph is a laser copy in sepia.

By the 1930s, the park area on the Cumberland Plateau was plagued by soil erosion and sub-marginal lands. The Work Projects Administration (WPA), Civilian Corservation Corps (CCC), Resettlement Administration, and U.S. Forest Service worked together to; make the land productive again. The WPA and CCC were work-relief programs that brought much-needed jobs during the Great Depression. The FDR administation's ""alphabet agencies"" were New Deal projects created to alleviate poverty and spur the economy.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Making sorghum molasses with electric machinery
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph depicts a man stripping sorghum stalks with an electricity-powered machine. He is hand-feeding the sorghum into a grinder to make molasses.

Farmers were large beneficiaries of the electricity created by the Tennessee Valley Authority. The New Deal initiative to harness power from a series of dams along Tennessee River provided the first electricity for millions in the valley. It; was established by Congress in 1933 and continues serving seven Southern states. TVA is the nation's largest public power provider. Sorghum is a food staple for poor and rural people.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pictorial Review, Civilian Conservation Corps, Distirct C, Company 420, Tenn. SP-12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Yearbook of the Company 420, Tenn. SP-12 in District C of the Civilian Conservation Corps in Bristol, Tennessee. There is a history of Company 420, as well as photographs of of the camp facilities and activities, including the mess hall,; woodworking shop, canteen, recreation hall and basketball team. There are pictures of the company officers and enrollees. Work projects featured include working on roads, stripping limestone, stone masonry, surveying and equipment maintenance.

The Civilian Conservation Corps was created by Congress in 1937 to succeeed the emergency Conservation program begun in 1933. Remedial education and vocational training programs were added later. The; mission of the CCC was to provide work for unemployed young people. The CCC built roads, homes, and furniture, and it was instrumental in the infrastructure of the Tennessee State Parks system and National Parks in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Shield-shaped red felt patch embroidered in gold and green thread with a tree, a surveying tool, and the letters ""CCC"" appearing at the top of the shield.

This arm patch reflects some of the areas of emphasis of the Civilian Conservation Corps work. In this case, forestry, conservation, surveying, and mapping are all suggested by the design of the patch.; This patch stands separate from the CCC insignia patch, the Company specific patches, and those chevron or stripe patches worn to designate a rank within the CCC.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: CCC Insignia Patch, Yellow
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Circular yellow felt patch embroidered in green thread with a tree-filled landscape and the letters ""CCC"" centrally located on the patch.

In 1939 this circular patch with the landscape design became the official insignia for the Civilian Conservation Corps. It was to be worn on the left shoulder and also on the Army-issue wool cap that paired with the CCC dress uniform.

The Civilian Conservation Corps was created by Congress in 1937 to succeeed the Emergency Conservation program begun in 1933. Remedial education and vocational training programs were added later. The; mission of the CCC was to provide work for unemployed young people. The CCC built roads, homes, and furniture, and it was instrumental in the infrastructure of the Tennessee State Parks system and National Parks in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: President's message to members of the Civilian Conservation Corps
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Text of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's radio message concerning the CCC is reproduced here in a 1937 CCC yearbook. The CCC insignia at the bottom of the page is enhanced with the specifications of Camp Cordell Hull in red and green marker.; The message is titled, "The Admiration of the Entire Country."

This volume of the "Official Annual of the Civilian Conservation Corps, 'C' District CCC, Fourth Area, 1937" was donated by James O. Rickman of Johnson City, TN. Rickman was with Camp Cordell Hull, Co. 1455, F-5 in the Unaka Range; of the Cherokee National Forest, and it is assumed that he enhanced the CCC insignia on this introductory page with the specifications of his camp. The CCC (1933-1942) employed nearly 3 million men who worked on conservation projects.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Civilian Conservation Corps in Tennessee Collection, 1933-1942

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Jimmie Driver and his Tennessee Playboys" band. Pictured are three guitar players, one fiddle player, one banjo player, a harmonica player, and a spoons player; each holding his instrument. The caption on the front of the photograph identifies Henry C.; Mattingly as their announcer.
"Jimmie Driver and his Tennessee Playboys" was a band made up of Civilian Conservation Corps workers. It was formed in a Tennessee Civilian Conservation Corps camp.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: President Frranklin D. Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Governor Hill McAlister
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: President Franklin D.Roosevelt, First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt, and Governor Hill McAlister seated in the back of an an open-air automobile. An unidentified man sits in the jump seat. Tall trees are in the background.

President Roosevelt visited Nashville at the invitation of U.S. Speaker of the House Joseph W. Byrns. The president's mission was to promote his "New Deal." Byrns, a Tennessee congressman, helped Roosevelt push through Congress many New Deal programs; designed to combat the Depression. The Roosevelts saw the James K. Polk and Sarah Childress Polk tomb at the Capitol; ate breakfast at the Hermitage Hotel; visited Andrew Jackson's home, The Hermitage; and made several stops in Madison.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mural, "The Development of Tennessee"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of a mural depicting Tennessee historical figures

Illustrator Dean Cornwell painted several murals in Tennessee during the Depression. The WPA and other New Deal unemployment relief projects funded many artists to create art for public buildings nationwide. This mural, in the John Sevier State Office Building, Nashville, depicts the development of Tennessee. Its companion, "Discovery," features John Sevier and other earlier Tennessee heroes. WPA artists painted murals in about two dozen Tennessee post offices, including Camden, Clarksville, Crossville, Columbia, Dickson, Lewisburg, Lenoir City, and Sweetwater.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houston, Sam, 1793-1863; Forrest, Nathan Bedford, 1821-1877; Jackson, Andrew, 1767-1845
